Intro.p: This is a simple text protocol in a "human readable form". Text protocol was chosen because it's easier to debug and implement on the client side. It does require some more overhead, but since server and clients do not communicate much anyway, this is not an issue.
We use two terms for "clients": client and user. At first, user was considered to be a registered or logged-in client. The two terms are used uncleanly though, so you may best think of them as equal.
Intro.h4: Formating rules: lines, words and sentences
Intro.p: All communication must be encoded in utf-8. Binary data is not permitted.

A line, also known as a message, consists of a single protocol command, plus its arguments, communicated as a single string, and terminated by a newline character (\n). Lines may be of any length; 600 KB long strings have been verified to worked in both directions. A natural implementation of the protocol will result in almost all lines being under 1 KB in length.

Each line begins with a command, written in capitals. The arguments of the command, which come next, come in two types: words and sentences. Word arguments are sequences of non-whitespace characters, and are separated from each other by whitespaces. Sentence arguments are sequences of words (separated by whitespaces), which are considered as a single argument. Sentences arguments are seperated from each other by tab characters (\t).
The word arguments of a command always come first, followed by its sentence arguments. The last word argument is separated from the first sentence argument by a single whitespace. Some examples:

ul.li:
, with 4 words and 1 sentence argument:
UPDATEBATTLEINFO 25903 1 0 -210360064 Trojan Hills v03

, with 10 words and 4 sentences:
BATTLEOPENED 4437 0 0 BlackHoleHost6 71.2.10.1 8626 10 0 0 -1213614804 Spring 104.0 Coastline_Dry_V1 The BlackHoleHost - Conflict Balanced Annihilation V9.46

Intro.p: (So, when a client talks to the server, if you want to include a tab character in a sentence, you can't!)

The following notation is used within the arguments of a command. A given argument should be assumed to be a word, unless {} is present, in which case it is a sentence.
{...} = a sentence arg
{...} {...} = two sentence args (which should be separated by a tab character!)
| = multiple choices for the argument i.e. "OR"
[...] = an optional argument
All commands, except for some developer/admin specific commands, are listed below. Their arguments are listed in order, and should be sent in that order.

In a small number of cases, the arguments of a command were different in earlier versions of the protocol. The details below refer to the latest version of the protocol, and assume that the client has all the latest compatibility flag present.

A client must maintain a 'constant' connection with the server, to ensure that network timeouts and disconnects can be detected. If no data is being transfered, the client must send commands to the server at regular intervals -- every 30 seconds is recommended. The server will reply with a command. If no data or ping command has been sent for 60 seconds, the server will assume a network timeout and disconnect the client. Similarly, if the client does not hear back within 30 seconds of a ping, it should assume the server has gone down.

When a client joins the server, the client will be notified about statuses of users only for cases where this status is non-zero. A client's status and battle status should be assumed to be 0, if not specified otherwise by the server. (This saves on bandwidth, not that we really need to...)

Most of the commands that notify about some changes are forwarded to the source of the change. For example: When a client sends a command, the server sends a command to all users in the battle, including the client who sent the command. This allows the client to synchronize their local status with the server's, after the server has verified that the status change is valid; therefore, it also serves as confirmation mechanism.

Any message can be prefixed with a message ID. For example:
'#123 SAY main hello world!'
is a valid command with message ID 123. The server will use this ID in any message sent as a reply, for example:
'#123 SAID main Betalord hello world!'
would communicate the greeting on to other clients with a command.

The message ID has only one function: to ease tracking server responses for the client. They makes it easier to implement commands that require multiple responses in both directions. You can also use them with / to measure your round trip time.
Message IDs should be non-negative values, within 31-bit range (so, 0 up to 2147483647). Negative values are reserved by the server for internal use.

If a valid 'server_email_account.txt' exists (in the same directory as server.py), then Uberserver will carry out email verification. In order to verify an email address: the server sends a four digit verification code to an email address, the user/lobby must send this code back to the server. Each verification code is valid for 24h, and allows max 3 attempts at verification. Currently, the same email address can be used to verify multiple accounts, but this may change in future.

If email verification is enabled, then it is required for registering a new account and for changing email address. In this case, both and cause a verification code to be created, and sent. The verification code is expected back in and respectively. It can be re-sent, up to three times, using .

Lobby clients should always assume that verification is enabled. However, if verification is not enabled, then all email address and verification code fields can be left blank (or fed arbitrary data). In this case, no verification codes will be sent, and all verification attempts will automatically pass.
By match-making, we mean a somewhat abstract way of automating the process of users finding each other in battle rooms and then starting a game of a type that they like.

Currently, we don't have match-making. We do have a command, and a compatibility flag 'm', which might one day form the basis for a match-making system. Contact a server admin if you are interested in developing this!
To be in sync means to have the same versions of all the content required to play a particular game (including the map, engine, dependencies, etc). See or the unitsync documentation for details.

Hole punching is a networking technique for establishing communications between two parties in separate organizations who are both behind restrictive firewalls.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hole_punching We use it to allow clients to connect to the lobby server, that would otherwise not be able to. See the commands , , , , .

At some point we hope to implement the command set. There are the only commands documented below that are currently unimplemented. These commands will allow to initiate games without creating/joining a battle-room.

Any client may host a battleroom, also referred to as a battle, which is (effectively) a special type of chat channel with extra features related to setting up and launching a multi-player game. A client may join at most one battleroom at any given time. This includes when the client is hosting the battle. The server automatically enforces this rule.
Clients detect whether a battle has a game currently in progress by monitoring the hosts status. For example, if the hosts status changes to "in game", then the battles is "in game".

spring.exe uses UDP connections for online multi-player games (TCP is not suitable due to latency). These connections are made between the host client (of the battleroom) and non-host clients. Consequently, the lobby protocol contains a set of commands dedicated to setting up UDP connections between host/non-host clients.
Intro.h4: Setting up UDP connections: non-host perspective
Intro.p: Before joining a battle, a client is expected to first acquire their UDP source port from the server. This is done by sending a UDP packet, which a response coming via . Once the client has done that, the client should keep sending UDP packets to the server at regular 20 second intervals, to keep the connection alive and ensure that the clients router does not remove the UDP connection from its port translation table. After spring.exe is launched, these UDP keep-alive signals may be discontinued (because then spring.exe will be sending regular UDP packets). Once spring.exe exits, the client should resume sending UDP keep-alive signals.

Just before starting the game, the host should send a command to the user, containing the host's public UDP source port. The lobby cient should replace the battles port with this one, as it will have to connect to the game using this port and not the original one (that was acquired through the command).
Note: If the client is not hosting, then it does not need to "punch through", which is does have to do when hosting, because spring.exe will take care of that. Todo: make this clearer!
Intro.h4: Setting up UDP connections: host perspective
Intro.p: Before sending the command, the host should try to acquire its UDP source port from the server, just to make sure it can acquire it at all (better to find out it does not work before hosting, than right before starting the game). However, the client does not need to keep this UDP connection alive, since it will not be used to actually host the game. It is just a test to see if UDP connectivity works.

When a new client joins the battle, the server will send a command to the host, informing the host of this client's public UDP source port. The host should remember this information, as he will have to use it when starting the game.

Right before starting the game, the host should try to acquire his source port again. This time he will actually use this port to host the game. Upon starting the game, the server will notify all clients participating in his battle about his port, using the command. The host does not need to keep refreshing his connection to keep the port open, as spring.exe will do that for him. Upon returning from the first game that was hosted in his battleroom, the host does not need to keep refreshing it either (as a client would have to do -- because when the host starts a new game it will have to acquire a new source port anyway).

This setup exists because some host clients might play "single-player" games with bots before opening their battleroom to other players, in which case any UDP port that was originally set up would have long ago timed out (spring.exe would not keep it alive during a single player game!). For this reason, the host has to acquire a new UDP port each time it starts a battle.
If this document doesn't provide what you are looking for, you may have a look at the Uberserver source code, in protocol.py, or ask for help in the #sy channel of the SpringRTS lobbyserver.

Arguments.Argument: The user's password string. If a client uses a secure session (which means the command itself shall be encrypted, including its arguments), it should send BASE64(password), otherwise it should send BASE64(MD5(password)).
A valid email address. Case will not be considered.

Command.Description:
The client sends this command when trying to register a new account. Note that the client must not already be logged in, or else the server will deny his request.
The username and password are given sanity/uniqueness checks, and these primarily determine the servers response. If email verification is enabled, and no valid email address is provided, the server will deny the registration.
Command.Response: or .

Command.Name: REGISTRATIONDENIED
Command.Description: Sent in response to a command, if registration has been refused.

Command.Name: REGISTRATIONACCEPTED
Command.Description:
Sent in response to a command, if registration has been accepted.
If email verification is enabled, sending of this command notifies that the server has sent a verification code to the users email address. This verification code is expected to be sent back in
Upon reciept of this command, a lobby client would normally be expected to reply with a attempt (but this is not a requirement of the protocol).

Command.Name: LOGIN

Arguments.Argument:
The user's password string. If a client uses a secure session (which means the command itself shall be encrypted, including its arguments), it should send BASE64(password), otherwise it should send BASE64(MD5(password)).
Note that when the server is running in LAN mode, any username and password will be accepted.
deprecated, set it to 0

The client should supply his local IP (e.g. 192.168.x.y, or whatever it uses) so the server can forward local IPs to clients behind the same NAT (this resolves some of the host/joining issues). If the client is unable to determine its local IP, he should send "*" instead.

This is a unique user identification number provided by the client-side software. It has to be an unsigned 32 bit integer which is generated by calculating the crc32 from the binary mac address of the primary network interface. If it can't be determinated it has to be set to 0.

When connecting, the lobby client can tell the lobby server that it is compatible with some optional functionalities that break backward compatibility. Each flag in this space separated parameter indicates a specific functionality (like IRC user/channel flags). By default, all the optional functionalities are considered as not supported by the client. For the current list of flags, see Recent changes - Version *-SNAPSHOT - Compatibility-Flags in the beginning of this document.

Sent by a client asking to log on to the server.
Note: if the client has not yet confirmed the user agreement, then server will send the to the client as a response to this command. In this case the response to will be delayed until . Command.Name: ACCEPTED
Command.Description:
Sent as a response to the command, if it succeeded. Next, the server will send much info about clients and battles:
multiple , each giving one line of the current welcome message

Command.Name: DENIED
Command.Description: Sent as a response to a failed command.

Command.Name: EXIT

Arguments.Argument: Clients may optionally specify a reason for quitting. If the user simply wished to exit, many lobby clients send their name and version.

Command.Description: Clients should send this as their last command before severing the connection to indicate a clean and deliberate disconnect.
Command.Response: The server is not required to acknowledge, or respond, to the exiting client. However, it may notify other clients via server messages or status change commands.

Command.Name: LOGININFOEND
Command.Description: Sent by the server, indicating that it has finished sending the login info, completing the sequence initiated by

Command.Name: AGREEMENT

Arguments.Argument: The user agreement is sent in "Text" format (.txt file streamed via socket).

Command.Description: Sent by the server upon receiving a command, if the client has not yet agreed to the server's "terms-of-use". The server may send multiple AGREEMENT commands, each of corresponds to a new line in the agreement text, finishing with an command. The client should send and then resend the command, or disconnect from the server if he has chosen to refuse the agreement.
Command.Response: No response is expected until is received. See that command for more info.

Command.Name: AGREEMENTEND
Command.Description: Sent by the server after multiple commands. This way, the server tells the client that he has finished sending the agreement (this is the time when the lobby client should popup the "agreement" screen and wait for the user to accept/reject it).
Command.Response: A response is not mandatory, but the server now awaits a command from the client, providing that the user agreed to the agreement. Otherwise, the client should disconnect from the server, and restart the sequence.

Command.Name: CONFIRMAGREEMENT
Command.Description: Confirm that the user agreed to the user agreement, and supply an email verification code (if necessary).
Command.Response:
, if the verification was either accepted or was not needed.
, if the verification code was not accepted.

Command.Description: Sent by the server after . The server may send multiple MOTD commands, each MOTD corresponds to one line of the current welcome message.

Command.Response: No formal response is required, although the server may reply with a .

Command.Response: No formal response is required, although the server may reply with a .

Command.Name: BAN

Arguments.Argument: The target of the ban.
In days, as a float.

Command.Description: Requests that the server add the corresponding user, AND their current ip, AND their current email address, to the server ban list.
Command.Response: None. The server will give a response via server message(s).

Command.Name: BANSPECIFIC

Arguments.Argument: The target of the ban.
In days, as a float.

Command.Description:
Requests that the server add the given arg (and nothing else, unlike ) to the server ban list.
The first argument can be either a username, an ip in the form 'x.x.x.x' or an email address in the form 'a@b.c'. The server will auto-recognize the input as one of these three forms, or respond with an error message.
Command.Response: None. The server will give a response via server message(s).

Examples.Example: BANSPECIFIC 216.3.128.12 7 shooting wabbits out of sheason

Command.Name: UNBAN
Command.Description:
Requests that all bans matching the given input be removed from the server banlist.
The first argument can be either a username, an ip in the form 'x.x.x.x' or an email address in the form 'a@b.c'. The server will auto-recognize the input as one of these three forms, or respond with an error message.
Command.Response: None. The server will give a response via server message(s).

Command.Name: LISTBANS
Command.Description: Ask the server to reply with a stream of server messages, containing a human readable version of the server ban list.
Command.Response: None. The server will give a response via server message(s).

Command.Name: BLACKLIST
Command.Description: Request that given domain be added to the blacklist. The server will deny verification attempts for all emails ending in a blacklisted domain.
Command.Response: None. The server will give a response via server message(s).

Command.Name: UNBLACKLIST
Command.Description: Request that the given domain be removed from the blacklist.
Command.Response: None. The server will give a response via server message(s).

Command.Name: LISTBLACKLIST
Command.Description: Ask the server to reply with a stream of server messages, containing a human readable version of the current blacklist.
Command.Response: None. The server will give a response via server message(s).

Command.Name: UDPSOURCEPORT
Command.Description: Sent as a response to a client's UDP packet (used with "hole punching" NAT traversal technique).

Command.Name: CLIENTIPPORT
Command.Description: Sent to the battle's host, notifying him about another client's IP address and his public UDP source port. The host needs to know public UDP source ports of all players in his battle in order for the Hole punching technique to work. The IP is needed for both NAT traversal methods ("hole punching" and "fixed source ports"). This command is sent to the the battle host immediately after a new user joins the battle (currently only if some NAT traversal technique is used).

Command.Name: HOSTPORT
Command.Description: Sent by the server to all clients participating in the battle (except for the host), notifying them about the new host port. This message will only be sent right before the host starts a game, if this battle is being hosted using "hole punching" NAT traversal technique. When a client receives this message, he should replace the battle's host port with this new port, so that when the game actually starts, he will connect to this new port, rather than to the port which the host selected when he initialy started the battle (with the command).

Command.Name: SERVERMSG
Command.Description: A general purpose message sent by the server. The lobby client program should display it either in the chat log or in some kind of system log, where the user will notice it. Also see the command.

Examples.Example: SERVERMSG Server is going down in 5 minutes for a restart, due to a new update.

Command.Name: SERVERMSGBOX

Arguments.Argument: If specified, the lobby client should ask the user if he wants this URL to be opened in a browser window. The lobby client should then (once the user clicked OK) launch the default browser and open this URL in there.

Command.Description: The client should open the message in a dialog window (and not just in the console). Also see the command.

Command.Response: 0 or more commands and finally by a command.

Command.Name: MUTELISTEND
Command.Description: Sent by the server after it has finished sending the list of mutes for a channel. Also see the and commands.

Command.Name: CHANNELTOPIC

Arguments.Argument: Time in seconds since Jan 1, 1970 (UTC).

Command.Description: Sent to a client who just joined the channel, if some topic is set for this channel.

Command.Name: CHANNELTOPIC
Command.Description: Sent a by privileged user who is trying to change a channel's topic. Use "*" as topic if you wish to remove the topic.

Command.Name: NOCHANNELTOPIC

Arguments.Argument: The Channel name which the client joined

Command.Description: This command informs the client that the channel it just joined has no topic set. Also see the and command.

Command.Name: CLIENTS
Command.Description: Sent to a client who just joined the channel. Note: Multiple commands of this kind can be sent in a row. The server takes the list of clients in a channel, separates it into several lines and sends each line seperately. This ensures no line is too long, because the client may have some limit set on the maximum line-length and it could ignore the line if it was too long. Also note, that the clients user-name is sent in this list too! So when the client receives a JOIN command, he should not add his name in the client list of the channel, but he should wait for the CLIENTS command, which will contain his name too and he will add himself automatically then.

Command.Name: JOINED
Command.Description: Sent to all clients in a channel (except the new client) when a new user joins the channel.

Command.Name: LEAVE
Command.Description: Sent by a client when he is trying to leave a channel. When the client is disconnected, he is automatically removed from all channels.

Command.Name: LEFT
Command.Description: Sent by the server to all clients in a channel when some client left this channel. WARNING: The server does not send this command to a client that has just left a channel, because there is no need to, as the client who has left the channel knows that already. A client that was kicked from the channel is notified about it via the command.

Command.Name: FORCELEAVECHANNEL
Command.Description: Sent by a client (moderator), requsting that a user be removed from the channel. The user will be notified with a command.

Command.Name: FORCELEAVECHANNEL
Command.Description: Sent to a user who has just been kicked from the channel #chanName by user "userName". The lobby client should now internally close/detach from the channel, as he was removed from the clients list of #channame on the server side.

Command.Name: CHANNELMESSAGE
Command.Description: Sent by the server to all clients in a channel. Used to broadcast messages in a channel.

Command.Name: SAY
Command.Description: Send a chat message to a specific channel. The client has to join the channel first, to be allowed to use this command.
Command.Response: See .

Command.Name: SAID
Command.Description: Sent to all clients participating in a specific channel when one of the clients sent a chat message to it (including the author of the message).

Command.Description: Sent by any client when he is trying to say something in "/me" IRC style. Also see the command.

Command.Name: SAIDEX
Command.Description: Sent by the server when a client said something using the command.

Command.Description: Send a private chat message to an other client.
Command.Response: See .

Command.Name: SAYPRIVATE
Command.Description: Sent to a client that just sent a command. This way, the client can verify that the server did get his chat message and that the receiver will get it too.

Command.Name: SAIDPRIVATE
Command.Description: Indicates that a user sent a private chat message to the receiving client.

Command.Name: SAYPRIVATEEX

Command.Name: MYSTATUS

Arguments.Argument:
A signed integer in text form (e.g. "1234"). Each bit has its meaning:
b0 = in game (0 - normal, 1 - in game)
b1 = away status (0 - normal, 1 - away)
b2-b4 = rank (see Account class implementation for description of rank) - client is not allowed to change rank bits himself (only server may set them).
b5 = access status (tells us whether this client is a server moderator or not) - client is not allowed to change this bit himself (only server may set them).
b6 = bot mode (0 - normal user, 1 - automated bot). This bit is copied from user's account and can not be changed by the client himself. Bots differ from human players in that they are fully automated and that some anti-flood limitations do not apply to them.

Command.Description: Sent by a client to inform the server about his changed status. To figure out if a battle is "in-game", a client must check the in-game status of the host.

Command.Name: CLIENTSTATUS

Arguments.Argument: See the command for possible values of this parameter.

Command.Description: Sent by the server to all registered clients, indicating that a client's status changed. Note that client's status is considered 0 if not indicated otherwise (for example, when you login, the server sends only statuses of those clients whose statuses differ from 0, to save bandwidth).

Command.Name: MYBATTLESTATUS

Arguments.Argument:
An integer, but with limited range: 0..2147483647 (use signed int and consider only positive values and zero) This number is sent as text. Each bit has its meaning:
b0 = undefined (reserved for future use)
b1 = ready (0=not ready, 1=ready)
b2..b5 = team no. (from 0 to 15. b2 is LSB, b5 is MSB)
b6..b9 = ally team no. (from 0 to 15. b6 is LSB, b9 is MSB)
b10 = mode (0 = spectator, 1 = normal player)
b11..b17 = handicap (7-bit number. Must be in range 0..100). Note: Only host can change handicap values of the players in the battle (with HANDICAP command). These 7 bits are always ignored in this command. They can only be changed using HANDICAP command.
b18..b21 = reserved for future use (with pre 0.71 versions these bits were used for team color index)
b22..b23 = sync status (0 = unknown, 1 = synced, 2 = unsynced)
b24..b27 = side (e.g.: arm, core, tll, ... Side index can be between 0 and 15, inclusive)
b28..b31 = undefined (reserved for future use)

Should be a 32-bit signed integer in decimal form (e.g. 255 and not FF) where each color channel should occupy 1 byte (e.g. in hexdecimal: $00BBGGRR, B = blue, G = green, R = red). Example: 255 stands for $000000FF.

Command.Description: Sent by a client to the server, telling him his battle status changed.

Command.Name: SETSCRIPTTAGS
Command.Description:
Sent by a client (battle host), to inform other clients about current battle configuration (start positions type, mod options, map options...). Only the battle host itself needs to write the corresponding script tags into script.txt, other battle clients should merely use them for display purposes.
The [pair] format is "key=value can have spaces". Keys may not contain spaces, and are expected to use the '/' character to separate tables, see example:
SETSCRIPTTAGS game/startmetal=1000
SETSCRIPTTAGS game/startenergy=1000
SETSCRIPTTAGS game/maxunits=500
SETSCRIPTTAGS game/startpostype=1
SETSCRIPTTAGS game/gamemode=0
SETSCRIPTTAGS game/limitdgun=1
SETSCRIPTTAGS game/diminishingmms=0
SETSCRIPTTAGS game/ghostedbuildings=1
Though in reality, all tags are joined together in a single command. Note that when specifying multiple key+value pairs, they must be separated by TAB characters.
All keys are made lowercase by the server.
See the examples bellow.

Command.Name: SETSCRIPTTAGS
Command.Description:
Relayed from battle host's message. A client lobby program must process these tags and apply them accordingly to the GUI presenting current battle configuration to the player.
All keys are made lowercase by the server.
